newsitem.title: POLAND: OSCE tells Albania leaders to respect poll result.
newsitem.headline: OSCE tells Albania leaders to respect poll result.

text.p: The OSCE, which monitored Albania's elections, said on Tuesday the polls had been acceptable and told Albanian politicians to honour the outcome and seek reconciliation or risk losing international aid.

"Without such reconciliation, there will be no basis for defining the terms of international aid, and the continued support of the international community," the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) said in a final report on the June 29-July 6 polls.
"We believe...we can say the elections can be deemed as acceptable, given the prevailing circumstances," the statement said, pointing to a high 73 percent turnout.
It said most voters had been able to cast ballots without fear and most electoral commissions had behaved impartially.
After two rounds of voting, Albania's ex-communist Socialists and their leftist allies looked set for a two-thirds majority over President Sali Berisha's Democratic Party.
The 54-nation OSCE, spanning Europe and North America, monitors human rights and democratic institutions in Europe.

Javier Ruperez, Spanish president of the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly meeting in Warsaw, told a news conference that the OSCE Albania mission's chief Franz Vranitzky would later submit conclusions to OSCE leaders who would decide on recommendations for future international aid.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has been waiting for a new government before negotiating terms of an economic reform programme. The IMF has disbursed some 60 million in credits to Albania since 1992 but the programme was suspended in 1995.
It reported that there had been irregularities in both the first and second rounds, some serious, which it was up to Albania's judicial system to deal with.

But referring to the June 29 first round it added: "The large turnout of voters (73 percent) demonstrated that Albania, in close cooperation with the OSCE, was able to organise the voting day in a reasonably orderly fashion."
It recalled that one polling station official had been killed in an apparently election-related murder, and said that the counting had been very slow and problematic.
The statement condemned the killing of two election officials in the second round, but added: "Overall, observers indicated that there were no serious technical violations of the voting process."

Albania's Socialist leader Fatos Nano, who plans to be prime minister of the coalition government, said on Monday he hoped to convene parliament by July 20 and form a cabinet by July 25 although some districts are to hold a vote on Sunday.

The early election was called in March after the collapse of popular savings funds triggered a violent rebellion and over 1,500 deaths in clashes, forcing the Democratic government to resign after five years of ruling the Balkan nation.
The Socialists won over 80 of 155 seats in the first vote.
